sub_topic: The search for new physics beyond the Standard Model
message_1: What is the probability of detecting Higgs Boson decay via the channel of photon-photon fusion at the LHC and how does it compare with other decay channels in the search for new physics beyond the Standard Model?
message_2:
The Higgs boson is an elementary particle in the Standard Model of particle physics, discovered at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in 2012. It is responsible for giving other particles mass through the Higgs mechanism. The Higgs boson can decay into various particles, including photons, W and Z bosons, bottom quarks, and tau leptons, among others.

The probability of detecting Higgs boson decay via the channel of photon-photon fusion (also known as diphoton decay) at the LHC is relatively small compared to other decay channels. The branching ratio for the Higgs boson decaying into two photons is approximately 0.23%, or about 2.3 events out of every 1000 Higgs boson decays.

However, the diphoton decay channel is particularly important in the search for new physics beyond the Standard Model because it provides a clean experimental signature. Photons are relatively easy to detect and measure, and the background processes that could mimic the Higgs boson decay into two photons are well understood and can be subtracted. This makes the diphoton channel one of the most sensitive channels for detecting the Higgs boson and probing its properties.

In comparison, other decay channels of the Higgs boson have higher branching ratios but may be more challenging to detect or have larger backgrounds. For example, the Higgs boson decaying into a pair of bottom quarks has a branching ratio of about 58%, but the large QCD background makes it difficult to identify the Higgs signal. Similarly, the decay into a pair of W or Z bosons has a branching ratio of about 21% and 26% respectively, but the final state particles can be more challenging to reconstruct, and the backgrounds can be larger.

In summary, while the probability of detecting Higgs boson decay via the photon-photon fusion channel at the LHC is relatively small, it is an important channel for the search for new physics beyond the Standard Model due to its clean experimental signature and well-understood backgrounds. Other decay channels may have higher branching ratios but can be more challenging to detect or have larger backgrounds.
